content.description: Start in the back of the cave on a good side pull with feet on the left wall, work through the roof crack using flaring hand jams and strenuous side pulls before making the big move to the slot at the lip and mantling over
content.location: Starts in the back of the cave right across from the currently unnamed dihedral problem, on the backside of rectangle rock in the jumble of boulders

content.description: Start on large ledge and move up into the dihedral on crimps and pockets to a narrow top out climbers left.
content.location: Follow the narrow corridor between Rectangle rock and the main wall. Boulder is located behind Rectangle rock

content.description: Traverse across the pockety face starting on the far left and finish by topping out Triangle Arete 1.
Starts on low on crimps and traverses on slopey arete. Same top out as Triangle Arete 1 Video Link
content.location: Follows the arete on the up-hill side of triangle rock.

content.description: Good rock quality. Pull through small edges to a bit of a committing last moves. Video Link
content.location: Located on the triangle boulder at the base of rectangle rock. Starts low on good edge on arete facing away from rectangle rock. Can down climb back of boulder.

content.description: The first 12-15ft of this route is the hardest part, once you get past this is becomes quite easy to top out. You can set a top rope but soloing it is pretty easy.
content.location: Walk on the left side of Rectangle Rock. Walk towards the corridor and this route is on the left before you enter the corridor.

content.description: Stand start with left and right hands on opposing sidepulls, move to sloping dish, and then up and left to a good (but hard to see) crimp. Then straight up (without use of the right arete).
content.location: Back of boulder on left side.

content.description: Start in the middle of Rectangle Rock and work your way left across the rock and then up to a top out.
content.location: Directly in the middle of Rectangle Rock

content.description: The first couple moves are the most difficult part, which are made up of mostly crimps. Once you get past these moves that holds are significantly easy. Climb about 10ft up to sloped/mossy finish.
content.location: On the left face side of the Rectangle Rock.

content.description: Follow the easy seam making liberal use of face holds
content.location: In the narrow corridor on the left hand side of rectangle rock

content.description: Climb up right slab of Rectangle Rock, once you reach the ledge the climbing becomes more difficult.
content.location: Right side on the face of Rectangle Rock.

content.description: Start with easy climbing on the obvious flake. Crux is after you reach the ledge.
content.protection: Anchors on trees at the top. Bring plenty of webbing and static rope.
content.location: The start is in the middle of rectangle rock on the obvious flake.

content.description: Climb the good holds in the middle of the pockety face to an easy top out. Video Link
content.location: Starts in the middle of triangle rock on the same side as triangle arete 1.

content.description:
Easy problem; good for new climbers or a fun warmup. 

 Start by balancing on the obvious ledge at the base of the pedestal. Move up to the left-hand side pull to reach high with the right to the big horizontal crack. Top out the same as Traversia.
content.location: Right at the front of Rectangle Rock. Easily visible as you walk up the path.

content.description: Start on the low incut crimps. Climb the arete to the top.
content.location: On the backside of Rectangle rock on the obvious fin/flake feature.

content.description: Normally shady, but does get some sun. Enough to dry out the rock in most open places. Open area with great views. Some of the better rock quality in the Hocking Hills.
